inquiryQuestions: How do we systematically name organic chemical compounds?

syllabusOutcomes.description: analyses the structure of, and predicts reactions involving, carbon compounds
analyses and evaluates primary and secondary data and information
solves scientific problems using primary and secondary data, critical thinking skills and scientific processes
communicates scientific understanding using suitable language and terminology for a specific audience or purpose

knowledgeNodes.description: Define and apply IUPAC conventions for naming straight and simple branched alkanes (up to C8), including methyl and ethyl side chains.
literacySkills: Number parent chain for lowest locants

knowledgeNodes.description: Define and apply IUPAC conventions for naming straight and simple branched alkenes (up to C8), indicating the position of the double bond.
literacySkills: Identify parent chain containing double bond
Number parent chain for lowest double bond locant
numeracySkills: Lowest locant determination (priority to double bond)

knowledgeNodes.description: Define and apply IUPAC conventions for naming straight and simple branched alkynes (up to C8), indicating the position of the triple bond.
literacySkills: Identify parent chain containing triple bond
Number parent chain for lowest triple bond locant
numeracySkills: Lowest locant determination (priority to triple bond)

knowledgeNodes.description: Define and apply IUPAC conventions for naming primary, secondary, and tertiary alcohols (up to C8), indicating the position of the hydroxyl group.
literacySkills: Identify parent chain containing hydroxyl group
Number parent chain for lowest hydroxyl locant
numeracySkills: Lowest locant determination (priority to hydroxyl group)

knowledgeNodes.description: Define and apply IUPAC conventions for naming aldehydes (up to C8).
literacySkills: Identify parent chain including aldehyde group
Recognise aldehyde group is always C1

knowledgeNodes.description: Define and apply IUPAC conventions for naming ketones (up to C8), indicating the position of the carbonyl group.
literacySkills: Identify ketone functional group (C=O within chain)
Identify parent chain containing carbonyl group
Number parent chain for lowest carbonyl locant
numeracySkills: Lowest locant determination (priority to ketone group)

knowledgeNodes.description: Define and apply IUPAC conventions for naming carboxylic acids (up to C8).
literacySkills: Identify parent chain including carboxyl group
Recognise carboxyl group is always C1

knowledgeNodes.description: Define and apply IUPAC conventions for naming primary amines (up to C8), indicating the position of the amino group.
literacySkills: Identify parent chain containing amino group
Number parent chain for lowest amino locant
numeracySkills: Lowest locant determination (priority to amino group)

knowledgeNodes.description: Define and apply IUPAC conventions for naming primary amides (up to C8).
literacySkills: Identify parent chain including amide group
Recognise amide group is always C1

knowledgeNodes.description: Define and apply IUPAC conventions for naming simple halogenated organic compounds (up to C8), indicating the position and type of halogen substituent(s).
knowledgeNodes.syllabusReference: CH12-14, M7: Nomenclature (ACSCH046 ref in sample unit)
literacySkills: Number parent chain for lowest locant set for all substituents

knowledgeNodes.description: Explore and distinguish different types of structural isomers, including chain isomers, position isomers, and functional group isomers, focusing on saturated and unsaturated hydrocarbons and simple compounds with one functional group.
literacySkills: Define chain, position, functional group isomers
Identify isomer types from given structures
examples: Isomers of C4H8 (but-1-ene, but-2-ene - position; methylpropene - chain)
Isomers of C3H8O (propan-1-ol, propan-2-ol - position; methoxyethane - functional group)

inquiryQuestions: How can hydrocarbons be classified based on their structure and reactivity?

knowledgeNodes.description: Construct models, identify functional groups (alkane, alkene, alkyne), and write structural and molecular formulae for homologous series of hydrocarbons up to C8.
literacySkills: Identify C-C single, double, triple bonds
examples: Drawing butane vs but-1-ene vs but-1-yne
Using Molymods or digital modelling tools

knowledgeNodes.description: Conduct an investigation to compare the properties (e.g., boiling point trends, viscosity, solubility) of organic chemical compounds within a homologous series (alkanes or alkenes or alkynes) and explain differences in terms of intermolecular forces/bonding.
literacySkills: Relate properties to intermolecular forces (dispersion forces)
numeracySkills: Graphing trends (e.g., BP vs C number)
examples: Trend in boiling points of alkanes C1-C8
Solubility of hydrocarbons in water vs non-polar solvents

knowledgeNodes.description: Analyse the shape of molecules formed between carbon atoms when a single, double, or triple bond is formed between them (tetrahedral, trigonal planar, linear) using VSEPR theory.
examples: Shape around carbons in ethene (trigonal planar)

knowledgeNodes.description: Explain the properties (boiling points, viscosity, solubility) within and between the homologous series of alkanes with reference to the intermolecular (dispersion) and intramolecular (covalent) bonding present.
literacySkills: Relate chain length/surface area to dispersion force strength
Relate intermolecular forces to physical properties
examples: Why methane is a gas but octane is a liquid
Why alkanes are insoluble in water

knowledgeNodes.description: Describe the procedures required to safely handle and dispose of organic substances (e.g. hydrocarbons), considering flammability and potential toxicity.
literacySkills: Describe safe handling techniques (fume cupboard, ventilation)
examples: Using hexane in a fume cupboard

knowledgeNodes.description: Examine the environmental, economic and sociocultural implications of obtaining and using hydrocarbons from the Earth (fossil fuels).
literacySkills: Identify sociocultural aspects (reliance on fuels, lifestyle)
examples: Greenhouse effect from burning fossil fuels
Impact on Indigenous communities near extraction sites

knowledgeNodes.description: Write balanced equations for the complete and incomplete combustion of hydrocarbons, identifying products (CO2, H2O for complete; CO, C, H2O for incomplete).
knowledgeNodes.syllabusReference: CH12-14, M7: Alcohols (Refers to combustion, implying hydrocarbons too)
examples: Complete combustion of methane: CH4 + 2O2 -> CO2 + 2H2O
Incomplete combustion of methane: 2CH4 + 3O2 -> 2CO + 4H2O or CH4 + O2 -> C + 2H2O

inquiryQuestions: What are the products of reactions of hydrocarbons and how do they react?

knowledgeNodes.description: Investigate, write equations and construct models to represent the addition reactions of unsaturated hydrocarbons (alkenes/alkynes) when added to: hydrogen (H2), halogens (X2), hydrogen halides (HX), water (H2O - hydration).
literacySkills: Write balanced chemical equations using structural formulae

knowledgeNodes.description: Investigate, write equations and construct models to represent the substitution reactions of saturated hydrocarbons (alkanes) when substituted with halogens (requires UV light).
literacySkills: Write balanced chemical equations using structural formulae

inquiryQuestions: How can alcohols be produced and what are their properties?

knowledgeNodes.description: Investigate the structural formulae, properties and functional group including primary, secondary and tertiary alcohols.
literacySkills: Classify alcohols based on carbon attachment
Relate structure to properties (e.g. solubility, boiling point)

knowledgeNodes.description: Explain the properties (boiling point, solubility) within and between the homologous series of alcohols with reference to intermolecular (hydrogen bonding, dispersion) and intramolecular bonding.
literacySkills: Compare strength of H-bonding vs dispersion forces
Relate chain length and H-bonding to solubility and boiling point trends
depthStudyComponents: Properties of homologous series of alcohols
examples: Why ethanol has a higher boiling point than ethane
Why smaller alcohols are soluble in water
Comparing boiling points of primary, secondary, tertiary isomers

knowledgeNodes.description: Write equations, state conditions and predict products to represent the complete combustion of alcohols.
literacySkills: Write balanced chemical equations for alcohol combustion
depthStudyComponents: Compare enthalpy of combustion for alcohols

knowledgeNodes.description: Write equations, state conditions (conc. H2SO4 catalyst, heat) and predict products (alkene, water) to represent the dehydration of alcohols.
Write equations, state conditions and predict products to represent the substitution reactions of alcohols with hydrogen halides (HX).

Write equations, state conditions (oxidising agent e.g. acidified Cr2O7^2- or MnO4^-) and predict products to represent the oxidation of primary alcohols (to aldehydes then carboxylic acids) and secondary alcohols (to ketones). Tertiary alcohols are resistant to oxidation.
literacySkills: Predict products based on alcohol type
Distinguish between aldehyde/acid formation for primary alcohols
depthStudyComponents: Oxidation of primary vs secondary alcohols

knowledgeNodes.description: Investigate the production of alcohols via substitution reactions of halogenated organic compounds with hydroxide ions.
literacySkills: Describe substitution reaction mechanism (SN1/SN2 not required)

knowledgeNodes.description: Investigate the production of alcohols (specifically ethanol) via fermentation of glucose.
literacySkills: Identify reactants (glucose), products (ethanol, CO2), conditions (yeast, anaerobic, warm)

knowledgeNodes.description: Compare and contrast fuels from inorganic sources (e.g., H2) to biofuels, including ethanol, considering environmental, economic and sociocultural factors.
literacySkills: Evaluate sociocultural factors (food vs fuel debate)

knowledgeNodes.description: Conduct a practical investigation to measure and reliably compare the enthalpy of combustion for a range of alcohols using calorimetry.
literacySkills: Identify sources of error (heat loss, incomplete combustion)
depthStudyComponents: Compare enthalpy of combustion for alcohols investigation
examples: Measuring ΔHc for methanol, ethanol, propan-1-ol

topics.topicName: Reactions of Organic Acids and Bases
inquiryQuestions: What are the properties of organic acids and bases?

knowledgeNodes.description: Investigate the structural formulae, properties (acidity) and functional group (carboxyl -COOH) of carboxylic acids.
knowledgeNodes.syllabusReference: CH12-14, M7: Reactions of Org Acids Bases (ACSCH127)
literacySkills: Relate structure to acidic properties (proton donation)
examples: Ethanoic acid structure and dissociation in water

knowledgeNodes.description: Investigate the structural formulae, properties (basicity) and functional group (amino -NH2) of primary amines.
knowledgeNodes.syllabusReference: CH12-14, M7: Reactions of Org Acids Bases (ACSCH127)
literacySkills: Relate structure to basic properties (proton acceptance via lone pair)
examples: Ethanamine structure and reaction with water/acids

knowledgeNodes.description: Investigate the structural formulae, properties (neutrality, H-bonding) and functional group (amide -CONH2) of primary amides.
knowledgeNodes.syllabusReference: CH12-14, M7: Reactions of Org Acids Bases (ACSCH127)
examples: Ethanamide structure, comparison of BP to acid/amine

knowledgeNodes.description: Explain the properties (boiling points, solubility) within and between the homologous series of carboxylic acids, amines and amides with reference to intermolecular bonding (H-bonding, dipole-dipole, dispersion).
knowledgeNodes.syllabusReference: CH12-14, M7: Reactions of Org Acids Bases
literacySkills: Compare extent/strength of H-bonding in acids, amines, amides
Relate intermolecular forces to property trends
examples: Comparing boiling points of ethanoic acid vs ethanamine vs ethanamide

knowledgeNodes.description: Investigate the production, in a school laboratory, of simple esters (esterification) between an alcohol and a carboxylic acid, identifying the conditions (conc. H2SO4 catalyst, heat) and naming the ester product.
knowledgeNodes.syllabusReference: CH12-14, M7: Reactions of Org Acids Bases
literacySkills: Identify reactants, products (ester, water), catalyst, conditions
examples: Ethanol + Ethanoic Acid --(H+)--> Ethyl Ethanoate + Water

knowledgeNodes.description: Investigate the structure and action of soaps and detergents, relating their cleaning properties to their structure (hydrophilic head, hydrophobic tail) and formation of micelles.
knowledgeNodes.syllabusReference: CH12-14, M7: Reactions of Org Acids Bases
literacySkills: Explain cleaning action in terms of emulsification

knowledgeNodes.description: Draft and construct flow charts to show reaction pathways for chemical synthesis, including those that involve more than one step.
knowledgeNodes.syllabusReference: CH12-14, CH11/12-7 M7: Reactions of Org Acids Bases
literacySkills: Use standard conventions for flow charts
examples: Pathway from ethene to ethyl ethanoate

inquiryQuestions: What are the properties and uses of polymers?

knowledgeNodes.description: Model and compare the structure (repeating units, branching, cross-linking), properties (density, rigidity, melting point, chemical resistance) and uses of addition polymers derived from ethylene (LDPE, HDPE) and related monomers (PVC, polystyrene, PTFE).
literacySkills: Define monomer, polymer, addition polymerisation, repeating unit
Relate monomer structure & polymer structure (branching, intermolecular forces) to properties
depthStudyComponents: Research structure, properties, uses of addition polymers

knowledgeNodes.description: Model and compare the structure (repeating units, functional groups like ester/amide linkage), properties (strength, melting point, biodegradability) and uses of condensation polymers (e.g., nylon (polyamide), polyesters like PET).
literacySkills: Relate structure (H-bonding, chain alignment) to properties
depthStudyComponents: Research structure, properties, uses of condensation polymers
examples: Nylon-6,6 formation and use in fibres
PET formation and use in bottles/clothing
